The very British reason why Prince George always wears shorts

share tweet pin email

When you see photos of Prince George, you probably focus on the 3-year-old’s sweet smile and cute chubby cheeks.

But there’s something else that people have noticed recently about the young royal: He’s always wearing shorts!

CHRIS WATTIE / Reuters The royal family arrives at a children's party in British Columbia, Canada Sept. 29.

Rain or shine, when the little prince steps out in public, he sports a pair of adorable shorts, often paired with knee socks, a preppy striped belt and a tucked-in polo (yes, at age 3, young George is already more put together than most of us will ever be.)

Pool / Getty Images Prince William, Duchess Kate, Prince George and Princess Charlotte arrive in Victoria, Canada.

Why is Prince George never spotted in jeans or other long pants? Harper’s Bazaar UK did some investigating, and they found that dressing young boys in shorts is a long-standing tradition among the British royalty and aristocracy.

AFP - Getty Images / AFP - Getty Images

The life of Prince George of Media madness - Two days after George's birth, British newspaper front pages show photographs of the royal baby and his parents. George was born on Monday July 22, 2013. Getty Images / Getty Images

“It’s a very English thing to dress a young boy in shorts,” British etiquette expert William Hanson told Bazaar. “Trousers are for older boys and men, whereas shorts on young boys is one of those silent class markers that we have in England. Although times are (slowly) changing, a pair of trousers on a young boy is considered quite middle class–quite suburban. And no self-respecting aristo or royal would want to be considered suburban.”

Prince George waves to the public and media as he visits the Lindo Wing at St. Mary's Hospital to meet his little sister for the first time. A photo posted by Kensington Palace (@kensingtonroyal) on May 2, 2015 at 12:27pm PDT

Most boys graduate to full-length trousers at about 8 years old, Hanson explained. He said the shorts-only tradition may stem from the antiquated custom of “breeching,” which dates back centuries in the U.K.

RELATED: Watch Princess Charlotte, Prince George play with balloons, bubbles during party

Traditionally, he said, young British boys were dressed in gowns for the first few years of their lives, until being “breeched” and graduating to short trousers.

MATT PORTEOUS / PA Prince George, who celebrates his third birthday on July 22, balances on a wooden swing. The picture was taken at the family's Norfolk home in mid-July.

Prince George is following in his father’s footsteps in the shorts department. The Duke of Cambridge sported a very similar look in his younger years:

Princess Diana Archive / Getty Images Princess Diana taking Prince William for his first day of nursery school in September 1985.

“The British upper set are always keen to hold on to tradition, and this one also silently marks them out from 'the rest,” Hanson told Bazaar.

However, though the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge may be following royal tradition when it comes to George’s shorts, they certainly aren’t elitist when it comes to where they buy clothes for their kids.

Chris Jackson / Getty Images Duchess Kate and Prince George visit the Royal International Air Tattoo at RAF Fairford on July 8.

RELATED: Prince George’s $39 robe sells out after he wears it while meeting the Obamas

Kate and William are known for dressing Prince George and Princess Charlotte in affordable, down-to-earth brands. Take these cute red corduroy shorts that George wore during the royal family’s recent trip to Canada:

Getty Images Prince George waves as he leaves from Victoria Harbour to board a sea-plane on the final day of their t our of Canada on Oct. 1.

They’re from London-based childrenswear brand Pepa & Co., and they cost the equivalent of about $20.

DonaCarmen.es

Keep rocking the shorts, Prince George — they couldn’t be any cuter!
